channel.title: I did the right thing... WHY?!
channel.description:
Well today I went to Future Shop to go and get my iPod Touch.. sold out. Pissed off, I had to drive a long way to get to Best Buy to get it.
The sales representative told me that she's going to take it out of the case (where all the other ones are stored) and by the time I get up to the register they will have it there for me, as a security precaution. As I was in line, she goes to me and says, "I'm busy soo.. I guess I could trust you with this." Hands it to me, and walks away to do her business. I realized I could then just walk out with something that's $280 and get away with it.
Why I did not take the chance? I don't fucking know..
By the way, the alarm at the exit would not have gone off because there are no security chips/etc.. in the iPod's casing. And even that, I could have just taken the iPod out of the casing by removing the tape..
WHY GOD WHY.

my point exactly. hoora, someones been paying attention

[quote=“Ske, post:50, topic:252921”][quote author=R.I.P RSC link=topic=334104.msg2604992#msg2604992 date=1230472921]
Religion is always tempting. There are many questions, such as why are we here, how did we get here, and what happens when we die. People have been thinking about this as long as they exist. They tried to answer these questions, but obviously, they couldn’t. So the best explanation would be a higher power. Something that created everything, something that looks after us. And, if you go back a few thousand years, explains natural events such as thunder, lightning or even the sun and the moon.

If I’m correct, karma is part of Buddhism. So is reincarnation (it doesn’t really matter what religion it is). This is another way to explain what happens after we die. It’s tempting too: especially when you think about it longer then a few seconds. I thought it over a while ago, and stumbled on something: How to explain the increasing number of humans? Where do all the souls come from? But the answer to that is simple: animals die. Which would mean that the number of humans and animals are connected, and never change.

But you need karma, and that’s where it derails. There is no such thing as karma. Some people don’t have luck in their lives, does this mean they did something wrong? African children, whose parents died, who suffer from aids: Did they do something wrong? I doubt it.
[/quote]
Yes, they did do something wrong.
The proof for me that karma exists, is that i already noticed this law before i even knew karma.

Im an observer, i really don’t like to talk too much like most of my friends.
They talk their way into life, i just observe.I think that’s why i notice some things most people dont.

anyway, the world is logical. You can compare the world to a game that is programmed with all kind of laws and many other things. For example: Luck, is determined by all kinds of things, it just doesn’t happen because you got “lucky”.
Karma determines your looks, your family, the enviroment you were born in. Just remember that it’s all logical.

Bring me 100 or maybe even 1000 people who disaprove with my opinion, i would still believe it 100% no doubt.[/quote]
Would you believe in my point though? That karma, while it doesnt govern the universe, exists soley for the individuals that believe in it. And Whether you notice it or not, nothing is different, other than how you perceive your world and how you explain good and bad things to yourself
